title: American_Top_40_1982_April_10th
description:
"I'm Casey Kasem counting down to the most popular song in the USA."


American Top 40 with Casey Kasem aired on radio from July 4, 1970 until August 6, 1988. This recording is a rebroadcast from internet radio.

In this countdown:

The Human League debuts their song "Don't You Want Me" (at number 39) and Paul McCartney & Stevie Wonder debut their new duet "Ebony & Ivory" on the hot 100 all the way up at number 29.

A listener wants to know if any song has hit the top 40 in each of the last three decades; the 60's, the 70's, and the 80's. Casey lists the top five, one of which is "Everlasting Love" which would also be a hit for Gloria Estefan in 1995.

Casey tells about the recording act that holds the record for longest streak in the top 40. This milk-drinking fellow stayed in for 169 straight weeks.

Since Bob and Doug McKenzie are at number 19 with their comedy bit "Take Off" Casey lists the ten comedy acts that have hit the top 40 in the rock era, two of which made the top 10.

Another listener asks, "What is the biggest number ever mentioned in the title of a hit song?" Casey lists some of the "big number" song titles that I'm sure I have never heard on any radio.

I didn't get my usual radio station this week. There are edits in segments 5 ("Centerfold" by the J. Geils Band, 9 ("Nobody Said It Was Easy" by Larue), and 13 ("Key Largo" by Bernie Higgins). In each song the tone changes for about 30 seconds.

LW#3: We Got The Beat - The Go Go's
LW#2: Open Arms - Journey
LW#1: I Love Rock And Roll - Joan Jett & The Blackhearts
